Massachusetts.title: Lowell Female Labor Reform Association.
Massachusetts.description: Lowell mill girls organized for 10 hour workday campaign.

Rhode Island.title: Slater Mill Strike.
Rhode Island.description: In May 1824, 102 women workers in Pawtucket, Rhode Island, left their looms after the mill’s owners announced a wage cut.Massachusetts 1844

Pennsylvania.description: Strikes of women workers rise out of the 10 hour workday campaign in western Pennsylvania cotton mills. Needlework design from stitchwork of Amelia Smith of Pennsylvania in 1837.

New Hampshire.description: New Hampshire became the first state to pass a 10-hour workday law. Sara Bagley, b. in New Hampshire, was a key figure in this effort. This motif is sampled from needlework made by 13-yr-old Louis Bean in the 1800s.

Ohio.description: The Female Protective Union in Ohio improved working conditions in garment factories by increasing pay and reducing hours which at the time were approx 96 hours a week.

Minnesota.description: Training schools for teachers open in Winona, Mankato, St. Cloud. For the first time, women are allowed to train for profession outside home

Mississippi.description: Newly freed black women, working as laundresses in Jackson, Mississippi, form a union and strike for higher wages.

Maine.description: Women shoe stitchers from six states form the first national women’s labor organization: the Daughters of St. Crispin.

Indiana.description: Virginia Claypool Meredith (1848-1936) earned the title “Queen of American Agriculture” in Indiana. She farmed in Cambridge City and was one of the first women to show livestock to speak about crop and livestock production. This motif is sampled from Sarah Jenkins, an 11 year old in 1800s Indiana.

Louisiana.description: Sugar Strike Louisiana. The Knights of Labor presented a list of demands to the Louisiana Sugar Planters Association on behalf of the sugar cane workers.  The Knights at that time did not exclude women or blacks and accepted workers of all skill levels. They are considered a predecessor of the Industrial Workers of the World.

Kansas.description: Mary Lease delivered speeches on behalf of Kansas farmers revolting against high railroad rates  and morgage interest rates. She believed big business made Americans into "wage slaves" and critiqued Wall Street.This motif was based on a Kansas quilt made made by Amanda Lewis or her daughter, Mary Jane Exoduster. Amanda first came to Kansas with her husband and children during the 1880s, settling near Concordia. She had lived as a slave in Kentucky before the Civil War.

Missouri.description: Kate O’Hare—machinist in the Kansas City, Missouri, shop where her father worked & joined the International Order of Machinists Union

New York.description: ILGWU formed 1900 / Women's Trade Union League (out of British org that led to the AFL) / supported Shirtwaist Factory 1911

Vermont.description: Addie (Laird) Card, 10-year-old Pownal mill worker photographed by Lewis Hines, becomes a “poster child” against child labor.

West Virginia.description: Fannie Sellins, labor organizer who worked with the mine workers union in West Virginia

Oregon.description: Oregon has the distinction of placing the question of votes for women on the ballot six times—in 1884, 1900, 1906, 1908, 1910, and 1912—more than any other state.

Colorado.description: “The women of the Colorado Fuel and Iron strike, 1913-14," Mother JonesFollowed the Ludlow Massacre.

Oklahoma.description: In February 1918 five of seven bookbinding companies in Oklahoma City agreed to increase wages when an agreement was struck between union members and company representatives. The new, two-year contract provided for $1 a week increase for men for the next two years. Women garnered a $1.50 a week increase the first year and a $1 a week raise in the second year. At that time men earned $24 a week, compared to $12 to $15 a week for women. By 1999 the median wage of Oklahoma women was $22,473, compared to $30,488 for men.

Delaware.description: Margaret Irving Handy of Delaware became the state’s first pediatrician. Later, Handy collected surplus breast milk in the community to feed the babies of mothers who could not breast feed, and established the first mothers' milk bank at Delaware Hospital.

Virginia.description: The same year women gain the right to vote, Virginia women account for 50% of all textile workers, 90% of all clothing workers, more than 80% of tobacco workers, and 45% of paper and print workers. This image of tabocco workers is from the same era. The motif was sampled from Sarah Jane Board of Oak Grove, made in the 1800s.

Nebraska.description: Amazon Army Omaha, unions in the northern plains

Wisconsin.description: In 1921, the Wisconsin Legislature passed the first equal rights bill in the nation, granting women full equality with men under civil law. The bill was signed into law by Governor John James Blaine and hailed by members of the Wisconsin Woman's Party.

Wyoming.description: Nellie Taylor Ross was the first woman governor in the United States and is the only woman to have served as governor of Wyoming. The Wyoming Territory was the first to give women the vote in 1869. This motif references a silhouette of an American Bison modeled after the state flag.

Tennessee.description: Margaret Bowen, a worker at American Glanzstoff, led a walkout of 523 women operatives.

North Carolina.description: Sept. 14, during the Loray Mill strike in Gastonia, NC, a Textile Workers Union members were ambushed by local vigilantes and a sheriff’s deputy.

Kentucky.title: Florence Reece, “which side are you on”, 1931 miner song
Kentucky.description: ‘Florence Reece, a shy, towheaded Kentucky miner's daughter, composed this song at the age of 12 when her father was out on strike. She sang it me standing in front of the primitive hearth of a log cabin in the backwoods of Kentucky in 1937 and it has since become a national union song.’

Alabama.description: General Textile Strike of 1934, Alabama 3 counties, then nation-wide

Michigan.description: 150 “sales girls” stopped working and stood proudly with their arms folded. The sit-down strike against the USA’s most unpopular chain store had begun.

Florida.description: Luisa Moreno unionized African-American and Latina cigar-rollers. She also became a representative of the United Cannery, Agricultural, Packing, and Allied Workers of America (UCAPAWA), becoming the editor of its Spanish-language newspaper in 1940.

South Dakota.description: National Youth Administration woodworking shop, Mission SD Todd County

New Mexico.title: Salt of the Earth film based on Strike 1951

Montana.description: In 1955, Montana attorney general Arnold Olsen declared that “Marriage is not a ground for dismissal” and that “teacher contracts could not discriminate against married teachers.”

Illinois.description: Betty Friedan’s Feminine Mystique published 1963, & Wages for Housework Chicago 1973 chapter

California.description: In 1965, Huerta directed the UFW's national boycott during the Delano grape strike. 1982 poster by Ester Hernandez

North Dakota.description: Commission on Status of Women, chaired by workers comp and AAUW, equal pay passed from commission in ND

Arkansas.description: Photographer Louise Boyle was invited to photograph the living and working conditions of the Southern Tenant Farmers’ Union members from several Arkansas communities.

South Carolina.description: Mary Moultrie and over 300 African American female hospital workers strike in Charleston, South Carolina for 113 days

Idaho.description: This motif is from an image of the Bunker Hill Mining Company in Kellogg, Idaho. Because of lead exposure concerns, the company required women workers to be sterilized if they wanted to work at the smelter. The union pursued research about the health conditions for both women and men and eventually it became a Superfund site.

Arizona.description: Anna O'Leary, who served as the president of the Morenci Miners Women's Auxiliary, copper strike Arizona 1983

Iowa.description: AFSCME Iowa Council 61 scores a $1.3 million win for AFSCME state employees victimized by sex-based pay discrimination.

Maryland.description: Gloria Johnson was a founding member of the Coalition of Labor Union Women (CLUW) and became it’s president in 1993. She worked on women’s and children’s health care, family and medical leave, and labor law reform. A life long labor leader in Maryland, she was appointed to President Clinton’s Commission on the Celebration of Women in American History in 1996. This motif is from a sampler made by Harriet Coopers of Saint Frances School for Colored Girls, Baltimore in 1849.

Washington.description: National and international non-governmental organizations— many concerned with labor issues, the environment, and consumer protection, created a mass demonstration at the World Trade Organization convention in Washington. The protests galvanized a lasting movement engaged with the struggles of globalization.
